subject: Bicycles and Bicycling
lead_paragraph: Lance Armstrong departed Australia confident that the two key areas of his comeback were on track. Armstrong, the seven-time Tour de France winner, finished 29th over all in the Tour Down Under. He was 49 seconds behind the winner, Allan Davis of Australia, but said he was satisfied with his ability to keep up with top riders after three and a half years out of professional cycling. Armstrong, 37, told reporters that his fitness was more advanced at this stage of the season than at any time in his career and that after his time away, he still has the legs to match younger riders. He also said that his quest for an eighth win in the Tour de France in July this year, the competitive goal of his comeback, was “right on line.”.
